briefdescription.para: State engine aware vTaskDelay wrapper.

parameterdescription.para: is how long to delay in ticks

briefdescription.para: State engine aware vTaskDelayUntil wrapper.

detaileddescription.para:
x
lasttim
is the variable storing the last delay time.
per
is the period.
This will cause the task to wait until the last time + the period.
Vehicle is in the process of initializing
Vehicle has initialized and is ready to drive
The settings of the vehicle are being edited now
The vehicle is actively driving
The vehicle is not allowed to produce any torque, but not full shutdown
The vehicle is presently in launch control mode
Some error has occurred here
Pre-init, when the boot loader is going
Stop literally everything, except for what is needed to reset vehicle

briefdescription.para: Type representing the overall state and operating mode of the vehicle.

detaileddescription.para: Type made to represent the state of the vehicle, and the location in the state machine The states are powers of two to make it easier to discern tasks that need to happen in multiple states
The SCD has issued no command, and therefore no action is required
The SCD has decreed that this task must be deleted
The SCD has decreed that this task must be suspended
OK for task to begin execution

briefdescription.para: Special commands used to start and shutdown tasks.

detaileddescription.para: Returned when a task was successfully deleted
Returned when a task is successfully suspended
Task was not successfully deleted
Task was not successfully suspended
Task has ended up in a fucked middle ground state

briefdescription.para: Response from a task confirming it has been either deleted or suspended.
Enum representing the state of a managed task.

detaileddescription.para: This is used as a flag to indicate whether or not the state_engine is aware of a task is running or not.

briefdescription.para: Priority of a managed task. Maps directly to OS priority.
Type representing the overall state and operating mode of the vehicle.

detaileddescription.para: Type made to represent the state of the vehicle, and the location in the state machine The states are powers of two to make it easier to discern tasks that need to happen in multiple states

briefdescription.para: Special commands used to start and shutdown tasks.
Enum representing the state of a managed task.

detaileddescription.para: This is used as a flag to indicate whether or not the state_engine is aware of a task is running or not.

briefdescription.para: Priority of a managed task. Maps directly to OS priority.
Struct to contain data about a parent task.

detaileddescription.para: This contains the information required for the child task to communicate with it's parent.
This will be a queue, since one parent task can in theory have several child tasks

briefdescription.para: Information about the task.
Settings that dictate state engine behavior.
This struct is designed to hold neccessary information about an RTOS task that will be managed by uvfr_state_engine.

detaileddescription.para: Pay close attention, because this is one of the most cursed structs in the project, as well as one of the most important

briefdescription.para: Function called at the end of the task period.
This function gets called when you want to create a task, and register it with the task register. Theres some gnarlyness here, but not unacceptable levels. Pray this thing doesn't hang itself.

inbodydescription.para: Do not exceed the number of tasks available
Acquire the pointer to the spot in the array, we are doing this since we need to return the pointer anyways, and it cleans up the syntax a little.

briefdescription.para: Create a new service task, because fuck you, thats why.

inbodydescription.para: Acquire the pointer to the spot in the array, we are doing this since we need to return the pointer anyways, and it cleans up the syntax a little.

briefdescription.para: make sure the parameters of a task_info struct is valid
ensure that all the tasks people have created actually make sense, and are valid
: This is a function that starts tasks which are already registered in the system

detaileddescription.para: This bad boi gets called from the stateChangeDaemon because it's a special little snowflake.

inbodydescription.para: The first thing we will do is check if the task is running, since this could theoretically get called from literally anywhere. If the task is running, then we check to see if t->task_handle is set to NULL . If it is null, that is a physically impossible_state. Neither very mindful or very demure.
That being said, if the task appears legit, then just update the corresponding bits in the tracker, and return that the task has aborted.

If a task has been suspended, we do not want to create a new instance of the task, becuase then the task will go out of scope, and changing the task handle to a new instance will result in the task never being de-initialized, therefore causing a memory leak. We want to call vTaskResume instead, and just boot the task back into existence.

If none of the previous if statements caught the task handle, then that means that either this is our first time attempting to activate this task, or the task has been deleted at some point prior to this one

briefdescription.para: Function that prepares the state engine to do its thing.

detaileddescription.para: This is called when the system is first starting up.

briefdescription.para: Actually starts up the state engine to do state engine things.

detaileddescription.para: This function ensures that all of the managed tasks are setup in a legal way, and then it allocates resources for, and starts the state engine and the background tasks. This unlocks the ability for the vehicle to do basically anything.

briefdescription.para: deletes a managed task via the system

detaileddescription.para: This function is the lowtier god of the program. It pulls up and is like "YOU SHOULD KILL YOURSELF, NOW!!" It sends a message to the task which tells it to kill itself.
The task complies. It does not have a choice.

inbodydescription.para: This checks with the RTOS kernel to see that the task as stated by the scheduler matches the state known by uvfr_utils

briefdescription.para: function to suspend one of the managed tasks.

parameterdescription.para: is a pointer to an int. If the task actually suspends, we update the tracker, since no further action is needed.
is a pointer to a uv_task_info struct.

briefdescription.para: Stops and frees all resources used by uvfr_state_engine.

detaileddescription.para: If we need to initialize the state engine, gotta de-initialize as well. This is the opposite of uvInitStateEngine

briefdescription.para: Function for changing the state of the vehicle, as well as the list of active + inactive tasks.

detaileddescription.para: This function also changes out the tasks that are executing, by invoking the legendary _state_change_daemon

state
is a member of uv_status, and therefore a power of two
returns
a memeber of uv_status depending on whether execution is successful
Example usage:
As you can see, all you need to do is specify the new state. Naturally, the task should be ready to get deleted by the state_change_daemon, but that is neither here nor there.

inbodydescription.para: If the state we wish to change to is the same as the state we're in, then no need to be executing any of this fancy code
Transition from UV_INIT to UV_READY states
Transition from UV_INIT to UV_ERROR states

memberdef.argsstring: (char *msg, uint8_t msg_len, const char *file, const int line, const char *func)
memberdef.name: __uvPanic

briefdescription.para: Something bad has occurred here now we in trouble.

detaileddescription.para: General idea here: Something bad has happened that is severe enough that it requires the shutdown of the vehicle. This can mean several things, such as being on fire, etc... that need to be appropriately handled
This should also log whatever the fuck happened.

The following should happen, in order:
Forcibly put vehicle into a safe state
Change vehicle state to error, and invoke the SCD
Log the error in our lil running journal

Should change vehicle state itself be the source of the error, we just need the software to completely fucking hang itself. If things are so fucked that we genuinely cannot even transition to the error state, then get that shit the fuck outta here, we shuttin down fr fr.

briefdescription.para: This function is called by a task to nuke itself. Is a wrapper function that is used to do all the different things.

inbodydescription.para: First lets load up the queue and the values in it. These come from the task we are doing.

briefdescription.para: Called by a task that needs to suspend itself, once the task has determined it is safe to do so.
